dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Two thousand points, Mark. The Dow just absolutely cratered.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Two thousand points, Mark. The Dow just absolutely cratered.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Dow Jones Industrial Average jumped nearly 500 points, gaining 1.7% and putting the index back within reach of its pre-coronavirus levels.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: I know, it's uh, completely wild. And the S&P 500 wasn't far behind, dropping over nine percent to a new record low.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: I know, it's uh, completely wild. And the S&P five hundred wasn't far behind, dropping over nine percent to a new record low.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The S&P 500 index rose 1.1% on Wednesday, hitting a new record closing high of 3334.69 and fully erasing its losses stemming from fears over the coronavirus and its impact on businesses and the global economy.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Right, but then you've got the Nasdaq surging past both of them, up like 8.4%? How does that even happen?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, but then you've got the Nasdaq surging past both of them, up like eight point four percent? How does that even happen?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Nasdaq Composite index, on the other hand, lagged both the Dow and S&P 500, gaining only 0.4%.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Well, it's all Tesla, honestly. Their shares skyrocketed almost 70% on Wednesday after reports that production in Shanghai was hitting record profits.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, it's all Tesla, honestly. Their shares skyrocketed almost seventy percent on Wednesday after reports that production in Shanghai was hitting record profits.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Nasdaq was held back in large part because Tesla shares, which soared up to 50% earlier this week, plunged by almost 20% on Wednesdayits worst day everamid reports that the coronavirus would impact production and deliveries at its factory in Shanghai, China.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: But wait, weren't they down 50% earlier this week? That's a crazy swing.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But wait, weren't they down fifty percent earlier this week? That's a crazy swing.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Nasdaq was held back in large part because Tesla shares, which soared up to 50% earlier this week, plunged by almost 20% on Wednesdayits worst day everamid reports that the coronavirus would impact production and deliveries at its factory in Shanghai, China.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and even with that huge jump, they're still down more than 70% for the year. It's just... volatile doesn't even cover it.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and even with that huge jump, they're still down more than seventy percent for the year. It's just... volatile doesn't even cover it.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Even with Wednesdays record plunge, Tesla stock is still up more than 70% in 2020.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And then there's the jobs report from ADP and Moody's Analytics—private payrolls fell by 500,000 in January. That's way worse than expected.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And then there's the jobs report from A D P and Moody's Analytics-private payrolls fell by five hundred thousand in January. That's way worse than expected.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Adding to the good news for the market on Wednesday was a report from ADP and Moodys Analytics, which said that U.S. private payrolls rose by 291,000 in Januaryalmost twice the expected number and the biggest monthly payroll gain in almost five years.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: The worst in almost five years. It feels like everything's just unraveling at once.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: The worst in almost five years. It feels like everything's just unraveling at once.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Adding to the good news for the market on Wednesday was a report from ADP and Moodys Analytics, which said that U.S. private payrolls rose by 291,000 in Januaryalmost twice the expected number and the biggest monthly payroll gain in almost five years.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Adam Crisafulli from Vital Knowledge called it—the bearish narrative is back in control.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Adam Crisafulli from Vital Knowledge called it-the bearish narrative is back in control.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The bullish narrative thats been driving stocks since late 2019 is firmly back in control of the tape after taking a brief pause during the final days of January.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: After that brief pause in late January, yeah. The market's just given up all those coronavirus-related gains.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: After that brief pause in late January, yeah. The market's just given up all those coronavirus-related gains.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The S&P 500 has now fully recovered from its coronavirus-related losses, turning positive for 2020 so far.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And he thinks the work improvements and travel freedoms from the pandemic ending will have much impact?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And he thinks the work improvements and travel freedoms from the pandemic ending will have much impact?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The coronavirus-linked work stoppages and travel restrictions will have a material impact on global growth, Crisafulli recently predicted.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Negligible, he said. Which is uh, pretty grim for global growth forecasts.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Negligible, he said. Which is uh, pretty grim for global growth forecasts.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The coronavirus-linked work stoppages and travel restrictions will have a material impact on global growth, Crisafulli recently predicted.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: So we've got crypto worries, major earnings losses, overvalued stocks...
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So we've got crypto worries, major earnings losses, overvalued stocks...

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: A perfect storm, really. Investors are in for a rough ride.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: A perfect storm, really. Investors are in for a rough ride.

artist_script:
HostA: Two thousand points, Mark. The Dow just absolutely cratered.
HostB: I know, it's uh, completely wild. And the S&P 500 wasn't far behind, dropping over nine percent to a new record low.
HostA: Right, but then you've got the Nasdaq surging past both of them, up like 8.4%? How does that even happen?
HostB: Well, it's all Tesla, honestly. Their shares skyrocketed almost 70% on Wednesday after reports that production in Shanghai was hitting record profits.
HostA: But wait, weren't they down 50% earlier this week? That's a crazy swing.
HostB: Yeah, and even with that huge jump, they're still down more than 70% for the year. It's just... volatile doesn't even cover it.
HostA: And then there's the jobs report from ADP and Moody's Analytics—private payrolls fell by 500,000 in January. That's way worse than expected.
HostB: The worst in almost five years. It feels like everything's just unraveling at once.
HostA: Adam Crisafulli from Vital Knowledge called it—the bearish narrative is back in control.
HostB: After that brief pause in late January, yeah. The market's just given up all those coronavirus-related gains.
HostA: And he thinks the work improvements and travel freedoms from the pandemic ending will have much impact?
HostB: Negligible, he said. Which is uh, pretty grim for global growth forecasts.
HostA: So we've got crypto worries, major earnings losses, overvalued stocks...
HostB: A perfect storm, really. Investors are in for a rough ride.
